subject: Re: [junit] Using JUnit Inside Application Server?
msgSnippet: I don t run Junit *inside* the application server, but I do run it as a J2EE client application to test my ejb s (which are running in the container).  The
messageBody:
I don't run Junit *inside* the application server, but I do run it as a
J2EE client application to test my ejb's (which are running in the
container). The setup is pretty trivial using RAD and Websphere, not sure
how it would work in the environment mentioned. I've also tested EJB's
using JUnit against JBoss. If I recall, for JBoss it was just a matter of
having the right classpath.

I suggest looking at that option.

-j




"Joakim Ohlrogge" <joakim.ohlrogge@...>

Re: [junit] Using JUnit Inside Application Server?






The reason would be that it is generally a bit more time consuming to
package and run your tests in an application server than it is from your
IDE. That is why I suggested running as big part as possible outside the
container during developmenttime.

If running your tests often does not feel that important then by all means
run them inside a container. I'm currently working with weblogic and I
can't
imagine TDD:ing if I would need to deploy my new code in the container in
order to run my tests. It is simply too tedious. In my case 95% of the
code
has nothing to do with EJB:s whatsoever so i don't see that much added
value
of executing the unittests inside the container.

That is just my opinion and also the reason why i don't know the answer to
how to run the tests inside the container. I never did it. Maybe it is
easier in other containers.

/J

> >
> > Extract as much as possible to classes that can be tested outside of
the
> > application server. The majority of the behaviour you are developing
can
> > be
> > and should be ignorant of wheter it runs in an applicationserver or
not.
> > For
> > system tests there is Cactus and MockEJB. I'm not convinced that it is
a
> > good idea to use those frameworks. I never felt had the need.
> >
> > I think in those cases deploy your application and run your tests as a
> > client. Perhaps using FIT or some other acceptance-testing framework.
> > Those
> > tests are typically run more seldomly than your unit-tests.
> >
> > This is just my opinion on a way forward. I'm sure those who disagree
> will
> > speak up soon :)
>
> There is no reason why you can't run your tests inside your container,
and
> if you are going to test an application that runs inside a container,
it's
> probably wise to run your tests there as well. The easiest way is
probably
> to package your tests in their own application (or bundle them with the
> application you are trying to test) and run them as a regular Java EE
> application.
>
